abstract.text: Animation type determines the type of supported animation,
being “for views” which provides an explicit property animator
(and implicit animation of sub-layers via CA transaction)
or “for layers” which provides the built-in implicit animations
(with adjustable duration/curve via this protocol).
Default is nil, which takes the type of the object getting
the control state updates. Note: in most cases it’s not
necessary to set this (i.e. just leave it to return nil by default)
because even in special cases where the control is a view
but the thing updated is a layer, wrapping the layer changes in a
view property animator (which is what will happen under the hood)
effectively provides the same animation as an implicit layer animation.
If you absolutely need implicit layer animations then return .layer.
To handle animations independently but still take advantage of theme-
based property changes being fired via control state updates
(presumably within the scope of animation blocks) return “.override”.
For example, in case “.override” is used you can then call
mutate.animate(..) { $0.highlighted(true) } which uses your
animator but still allows the highlight to update the visual
appearance according to the control state update.
This will also allow implicit layer animations to proceed as normal.
To stop all animations return 0.0 from “controlStateAnimationDuration”.
Exclusive buttons support exclusive selection state
within a group of sibling Exclusive buttons.
(Similar to a “radio group” in web programming,
and functionally similar to UISegmentedControl.)
ExclusiveControlButton is automatically “control state
updatable” for theme changes on the button itself and
potentially on a ControlBackground (layer) if it exists.
(This also presumes the button or super type (e.g. UIView)
conforms to ThemeAccessible or ThemeOverridable.)
